Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: AIS - An Integrated Optimization and Prediction Framework for Machine Intelligence based on Adaptive Dynamic Programming

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches:
The objective of this project is to advance the understanding, principles, and applications of a new learning framework that integrates optimization and prediction based on adaptive dynamic programming. The approach is to integrate a reference network into the adaptive dynamic programming design to link optimization and prediction by providing the internal reinforcement/goal representation. The proposed architecture can be designed in a hierarchical way, in which different levels of internal reinforcement signals can be developed to represent multi-level goals for an intelligent system.

Intellectual Merit:
This project proposes a new reference network to the adaptive dynamic programming design to integrate optimization and prediction capabilities for brain-like intelligence research. This structure provides a new approach to adaptively build the internal reinforcement signal rather than crafted by hand. The underlying principle and mathematical foundation of using internal reinforcement/goal representation could potentially bring cognitive optimization and prediction closer to reality.

Broader Impacts:
This research has the potential to develop innovative techniques for a wide range of applications, such as power grid control and communication/network systems. In addition to the benefits for academia and industry, this project will also benefit national and government interests as well, such as providing technical innovations for the U.S. energy security and sustainability objective (e.g., smart grid). The integrated research and education plan will not only promote excellence in education at different levels, but it will also enrich the participation of students with different backgrounds and encourage women and minority students to enter this field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed the theoretical foundations, architectures, and algorithms of a new framework of adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) named goal-representation ADP (Gr-ADP) for improved learning and decision-making. Unlike the traditional ADP approaches with two networks (an action network and a critic network), the Gr-ADP framework integrates an additional network, goal network, to provide an informative and detailed internal goal representation to support the learning and decision-making process. Compared to the existing ADP and reinforcement learning (RL) approaches with a manual or "hand-crafted" reinforcement signal design, the Gr-ADP framework automatically and adaptively develops the internal reinforcement signal over time. This goal network can also be designed in a hierarchical way, in which different levels of internal reinforcement signals can be developed to represent multi-level goals for an intelligent system. This is a fundamental difference compared to the existing reinforcement representation in the current ADP and RL literature.

The outcomes of this project are significant, ranging from new knowledge and methods to advance the machine intelligence research and development, to education and outreach programs across electrical, energy, robotics, and computer disciplines. The PI developed three specific families of Gr-ADP architectures and algorithms, as well as their associated theoretical characteristics: goal-representation heuristic dynamic programming (Gr-HDP), goal-representation dual heuristic dynamic programming (Gr-DHP), and goal-representation globalized dual heuristic dynamic programming (Gr-GDHP). This basically closed the loop and provided a complete new set of the Gr-ADP solutions for the community. Based on this new Gr-ADP framework, the PI also developed a wide range of applications for different types of complex engineering systems, including, power and energy systems, multi-agent systems, human-robot interaction, to name a few. These applications have demonstrated the capability of the Gr-ADP framework on a wide-range of real world applications.

The PI published a series of high impact journal and conference papers (e.g., IEEE International Conference on Communications (ICC'14) Best Paper, IEEE International Joint Conference on Neural Networks (JCNN’16) Best Student Paper, IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security cover page highlighted paper, IEEE Communications Society Best Readings) and received numerous awards (e.g., IEEE Computational Intelligence Society Outstanding Early Career award, Providence Business News (PBN) "Rising Star Innovator of the Year" award, conferred by the state governor of Rhode Island), among others.

The outcomes of this project on human resource impacts are also significant. This project provided unique opportunities for students to work on cutting-edge research problems in machine intelligence and its wide applications, leading to productive research results as well as intensive students training. One notable outcome is that five Ph.D. students graduated during this project period and they all joined academia as a tenure-track assistant professor in the research universities in U.S. and Canada. 

The education and outreach outcomes of this project are also significant, including the organization of several workshops and symposiums (e.g., IEEE Workshop on "New Frontiers in Computational Intelligence: From Foundations to Applications," IEEE Symposium Series on Computational Intelligence (IEEE SSCI)), development of new curricular (e.g., ELE 594: Computational Intelligence and Adaptive Systems, ELE 594: Reinforcement Learning and Adaptive Dynamic Programming, ELE 425: Renewable and Efficient Electric Power Systems), outreach to the Community College of Rhode Island (CCRI, the largest community college in New England, with about 60% female students), among others. All of these have developed unique platforms in educating and training students in research and encourage women to study Electrical/Computer Engineering disciplines.
